awd_abstract_narration:
Theoretical physics is the search for concise mathematical models of Nature. It has had great success in dealing with the inanimate world: we can now predict in quantitative detail what the most sensitive experiments will observe inside the nucleus and in the cosmos at large. By contrast, even as our ability to observe and measure improves dramatically, the phenomena of life remain largely unpredictable, even in their most qualitative aspects. In this project, a group of theoretical physicists will engage with students and postdoctoral scholars in an effort to close this gap; in short, to construct a theoretical physics of biological systems. The proponents have explored phenomena that span the tree of life: from metabolism in bacteria, through the determination of cell fate in embryonic development, to coding and computation of sensory information in brain. They have identified broad theoretical problems which cut across the traditional biological divisions of organism and system: Do living organisms operate near the limits set by the laws of physics as they gather and process information? Can we learn the detailed microscopic "model" of an organism, its "wiring diagram", from the finite set of observations we can make on how it behaves? How do organisms set the parameters that govern their function (i.e. how do they learn from experience)? These questions can all be given a mathematical form which guides a search for answers in terms of general principles, in the tradition of physics that will apply across disparate biological domains. The time is right to bring the beautiful phenomena of life under the powerful predictive umbrella of theoretical physics. Just as cosmology has progressed, in roughly one generation, from wild speculation to a precise framework for analyzing a rapidly expanding set of observations, the proponents believe that the intimate interaction between theory and experiment can lead to a new and deeper physics of biological systems. It is the creation of this scientific culture, where theory and experiment are equal partners in the exploration of life that is the fundamental intellectual merit of the project. It is not just the boundaries of academic disciplines, but our view of ourselves, which is at stake. A very important aspect of this project will be the training of a new generation of physicists for whom the development of a theoretical understanding of biological systems is a central part of their discipline. The graduate students and postdoctoral scholars who pass through the group will learn by example how to pursue that goal in a way consistent with the intellectual rigor and traditions of physics. They will eventually move on to faculty positions of their own, where they will transmit this attitude to new generations of students. More broadly, all project personnel are deeply engaged with new educational initiatives, addressing levels from the first year of college to advanced PhD students, which provide a more complete guide to the evolving, multidisciplinary intellectual landscape.

The participants in the project will assemble into subgroups to attack instances of these problems. The individual projects will have unusual scope: as an example, the question whether we can capture the complex statistics of biological behavior in a learnable mathematical model can be asked in very similar terms both of spiking retinal neurons, and of the antibody sequence repertoire of individual zebrafish. If the answer is yes and the models have similar mathematical structure, one will have learned something novel and deep about what makes evolved, living, systems different from the inanimate world. Since these questions can only be answered in the light of accurate data, the work will involve a close partnership with many experimental groups in fields ranging from bacteriology to human perceptual psychology. The product of these interactions will be the design of novel experiments and the creation of novel data analysis methods in order to address clearly formulated mathematical questions of broad significance. 

This project is being jointly supported by the Physics of Living Systems program in the Division of Physics, the Cellular Cluster and the Systems and Synthetic Biology in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences, and the Neural Systems Cluster in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the three co-PIs under this grant is to show that the living world is describable in mathematical language and subject to mathematical laws, just like the inanimate world. But even bacterial cells are dauntingly complex, and no Newtonian breakthrough is expected anytime soon. Instead, in this project, we have taken first steps toward this goal, a few of which we summarize below.

Biologists have recently discovered that eukaryotic cells are home to many non-membrane-bound compartments that form and dissolve as needed for the cell to function. These dynamical "liquid droplets" of special protein molecules enable many central cellular functions, from ribosome assembly, to RNA regulation and storage, to signaling and metabolism. What controls their formation, how are specific biological components included or excluded, and how do these structures influence physiological and biochemical processes are topics of intense interest. Wingreen has worked on identifying the biophysical principles underpinning the behavior of these condensates, focusing on phase separation dynamics in the cell nucleus. A collaboration with experimentalist Brangwynne using optogenetics revealed that droplet growth dynamics are directly inhibited by the densely packed DNA that fills the nucleus. Phase separation is also suppressed by a magic-number effect, which occurs when two polymers can form fully bonded small oligomers by virtue of the number of binding sites in one polymer being an integer multiple of the number of binding sites of the other. Fig. 1 shows a molecular dynamics simulation, based on these results, showing how molecules that attract each other (red), but are inhibited in their ability to move about by the chromosome environment (grey), slowly form the large droplets of molecules needed to carry out critical functions.

Callan has developed a statistical approach to the adaptive immune system. In a human individual there are billions of distinct types of T- and B-cells, each type expressing a surface protein whose job is to detect one of many possible pathogens. The different types of immune cell are created by random DNA editing that occurs when a new immune cell is created from a stem cell. The question is whether the diversity of an individual's repertoire of immune cells is enough to cover all possible pathogen threats. High-throughput sequencing technology gives us large samples of the receptor repertoire of an individual subject, and Callan and collaborators have used this data to develop a method for finding the probability that any particular receptor sequence will be produced when a new immune cell is made. Fig. 2 shows the distribution of these generation probabilities in a typical sample of human T cells. They range over twenty orders of magnitude and, since the human immune system contains "only" a few billion types of T cells, this means that there will be little overlap between individuals. Each person is a different "draw" from an overall probability distribution. Understanding how different individuals protect themselves from the same pathogen threats is a statistical question revealed and addressed by this project. 

The mechanisms of life can operate with extraordinary precision, sometimes reaching limits set by the laws of physics.  Thus, in the bright noontime sun the quality of the image formed on our retina is limited by diffraction though the eye's pupil, while on a dark night we can count individual quanta of light as they arrive at the retina.  Bialek and colleagues have long been interested in whether this approach to physical limits is more general, and whether it can be promoted to a theoretical principle from which aspects of the underlying mechanisms can be derived. In this project we showed that the same principle of squeezing maximally reliable information out of physically limited signals could be used to derive mechanisms at work in two very different systems, the genetic networks operating in the early stages of a developing fly embryo and the algorithms which the visual system uses to compute motion.  In the case of visual motion, we worked with experimentalists to analyze the statistical structure of natural movies and motions, showing that even optimal estimates of motion will result in systematic errors over a wide range of conditions, systematic errors that mimic those made by real visual systems, from flies to humans. In the embryo, if the underlying genetic networks use the optimal strategy for reading out information encoded in the concentration of crucial molecules ~2.5 hours after the egg is laid, then we can just manage to explain the fact that subsequent markers are positioned with an accuracy of ~1% along the length of the embryo.  This optimal estimator predicts, quantitatively and with no free parameters, the distortions in body plan that result from deleting the normal inputs to this network (Figure 3). Thus, the same principle leads to successful predictions in two very different biological systems.
